description.short: Measures vulnerability to attentional narrowing under stress that causes security teams to miss critical peripheral security indicators while focusing exclusively on immediate obvious threats
description.context: Stress-induced tunnel vision represents a fundamental neurobiological response where acute or chronic stress narrows cognitive processing to focus exclusively on immediate perceived threats while filtering out peripheral information crucial for comprehensive security assessment. This phenomenon occurs through activation of the sympathetic nervous system and HPA axis, which floods the system with stress hormones creating a cognitive 'spotlight' that illuminates only a fraction of the total information environment. The mechanism operates through attentional narrowing, working memory degradation, and increased reliance on heuristic shortcuts that may be inappropriate for novel or complex security threats.
description.impact: Organizations with high-stress environments systematically miss security incidents that fall outside their immediate focus area. The Target breach (2013) exemplifies this - overwhelming alerts caused teams to miss sophisticated APT indicators while focused on known threat patterns. During high-stress periods, response times increase, false positive/negative rates worsen, and complex multi-vector attacks succeed while teams remain focused narrowly on initial attack symptoms rather than comprehensive threat landscape assessment.
description.psychological_basis: Yerkes-Dodson Law demonstrates performance follows an inverted-U curve relative to arousal levels - beyond optimal arousal, increased stress leads to performance degradation, with complex cognitive tasks showing earlier degradation than simple tasks. Easterbrook's cue utilization theory explains how stress narrows attention span exponentially. LeDoux's research on the amygdala shows stress responses occur 300-500ms before conscious awareness, meaning tunnel vision effects begin before individuals recognize they are experiencing stress.

No formal scope assessment or single-threat assumption standard. Cross-team consultation occurs in less than 50% of complex security events.

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: Crisis Response Time Allocation
items.question: During your last major security incident, what percentage of the response team's time was spent on comprehensive threat hunting versus addressing the most obvious symptoms?

options.label: Balanced - 40%+ time spent on comprehensive analysis and multi-vector threat hunting
Moderate - 20-40% time on comprehensive analysis, majority on immediate symptoms
Narrow - Less than 20% time on comprehensive analysis, almost exclusive focus on obvious symptoms

items.evidence_required: Incident timeline documentation, activity logs, specific time allocation examples
items.soc_mapping: Activity time allocation from incident response system logs

items.title: Alert Investigation Depth
items.question: When your security team receives multiple high-priority alerts simultaneously, what is your standard procedure for ensuring all alerts receive thorough investigation?

options.label: Documented parallel investigation procedures with evidence of consistent use during multi-alert scenarios
Procedures exist but inconsistently applied, some alerts receive reduced investigation during pressure
No parallel procedures, alerts investigated sequentially with later alerts often neglected

items.evidence_required: Alert investigation procedures, recent multi-alert scenario documentation

items.title: Cross-Team Communication Under Pressure
items.question: How often do your security analysts consult with other teams (network, application, compliance) when investigating complex security events during high-stress periods?

options.label: Consistent consultation in 80%+ of complex events with documented cross-team involvement
Moderate consultation in 50-80% of events, reduced during highest stress periods
Rare consultation in less than 50% of events, siloed investigation during stress

items.evidence_required: Cross-team consultation records, collaboration platform logs, recent incident examples

items.title: Incident Response Scope Assessment
items.question: What's your documented process for determining whether a security incident might be part of a larger, coordinated attack rather than an isolated event?

options.label: Formal scope assessment protocol with documented multi-vector checks and evidence of consistent use
Informal scope assessment, sometimes performed but not systematically documented
No formal process, single-threat assumption standard unless evidence forces broader view

items.evidence_required: Scope assessment procedure documentation, recent incident scope analysis examples

items.title: Decision Validation Under Time Pressure
items.question: When facing urgent security decisions (system shutdown, access revocation, emergency patches), what's your process for double-checking these decisions before implementation?

options.label: Required two-person validation for all critical actions with documented verification
Validation recommended but can be bypassed during 'emergency' situations
No validation requirement, single decision-maker for urgent actions

items.evidence_required: Decision validation procedures, recent critical decision examples with validation records
items.soc_mapping: Decision validation patterns from audit logs during high-stress periods

items.title: Resource Allocation During Crisis
items.question: How does your organization ensure that routine security monitoring continues when the team is focused on active incident response?

options.label: Routine monitoring continues during 90%+ of incidents with designated 'business as usual' team
Routine monitoring reduced but not eliminated, some coverage maintained
Routine monitoring completely stops during active incident response

items.evidence_required: Staffing procedures during incidents, monitoring coverage logs during recent incidents
items.soc_mapping: Alert investigation rates for routine alerts during active incidents

items.title: Post-Incident Comprehensive Review
items.question: After resolving security incidents, how often do you discover additional attack vectors or indicators that were initially missed during the response?

options.label: Rare - Less than 20% of incidents reveal significant missed indicators in post-analysis
Occasional - 20-40% of incidents reveal some missed indicators during initial response
Frequent - More than 40% of incidents reveal significant missed indicators post-resolution

items.evidence_required: Post-incident review documentation, missed indicator tracking, recent discovery examples
items.soc_mapping: Post-incident discovery rate tracked through review system

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: During your last major security incident, walk me through how the response team allocated their time between addressing immediate symptoms and comprehensive threat hunting. What exactly did they focus on hour by hour?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific time allocation showing balanced focus, documented comprehensive analysis, evidence of multi-vector investigation
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some comprehensive analysis but majority of time on immediate symptoms, incomplete documentation
scoring_guidance.red: Exclusive focus on obvious symptoms, no comprehensive threat hunting, single-threat assumption

followups.text: Show me the incident timeline with activity breakdowns - where did the team spend each hour?
Were there any security indicators you discovered after the incident that were present during response but missed?

items.text: Give me a recent example where you had 5+ critical security alerts within a 2-hour window. How did your team handle investigating all of them thoroughly?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific example showing parallel investigation, all alerts investigated, documented procedures followed
scoring_guidance.yellow: Mixed response with some alerts deprioritized, partial investigation of lower-priority items
scoring_guidance.red: Sequential handling with later alerts neglected, tunnel vision on first or most obvious alert

followups.text: Which alerts received full investigation and which received reduced attention - why?
Did any of the lower-priority alerts turn out to be significant in retrospect?

items.text: Tell me about a recent incident where cross-team consultation (network, application, compliance) either helped or would have helped understand the full scope. What actually happened?

scoring_guidance.green: Specific example showing proactive cross-team consultation revealing broader scope, documented collaboration
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some cross-team communication but delayed or incomplete, missed opportunities for collaboration
scoring_guidance.red: Siloed investigation, no cross-team consultation, or consultation only after escalation

followups.text: At what point in the incident did you involve other teams - immediately or after initial investigation?
Show me the communication records between teams during this incident

items.text: What's your documented process for determining whether a security incident might be part of a larger coordinated attack? Walk me through how this worked in your most recent significant incident.

scoring_guidance.green: Formal scope assessment protocol with documented multi-vector checks, evidence of systematic use
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal scope assessment sometimes performed, inconsistent application
scoring_guidance.red: No formal process, scope discovered reactively rather than assessed proactively

followups.text: Show me the scope assessment checklist or procedure document
Have you ever discovered a multi-vector attack after initially treating it as single-vector?

items.text: Tell me about a time when your team faced an urgent security decision under pressure. How did you validate the decision before implementing it?

scoring_guidance.green: Required validation process with documented two-person review, examples of validation preventing errors
scoring_guidance.yellow: Some validation but can be bypassed for 'emergencies', inconsistent application
scoring_guidance.red: No validation requirement, single decision-maker under pressure, decisions regretted in retrospect

followups.text: Have you ever made a decision during an incident that you later wished you'd validated more thoroughly?
Show me the approval records for critical decisions during your last major incident

items.text: During your last major incident, how did you ensure routine security monitoring continued? Give me specific examples of what was and wasn't monitored.

scoring_guidance.green: Dedicated team maintained routine monitoring, evidence of continued coverage, specific examples
scoring_guidance.yellow: Partial monitoring continued with reduced coverage, some gaps acknowledged
scoring_guidance.red: All resources diverted to incident, routine monitoring suspended, no coverage maintained

followups.text: Show me the alert logs during the incident - were routine alerts still being investigated?
What's your staffing policy for maintaining coverage during extended incidents?

solutions.title: Incident Response Decision Trees
solutions.description: Implement mandatory decision trees for all security incidents that force consideration of multiple attack vectors before proceeding
solutions.implementation: Create detailed decision trees with specific checkpoints: 'Have you checked for lateral movement?', 'Have you verified this isn't a distraction attack?', 'What systems weren't affected?', 'Have you consulted with network/app/compliance teams?'. Require documented completion of all checkpoints before incident closure. Integrate into incident management system with automatic reminders.
solutions.technical_controls: Decision tree workflow in incident management platform; automated checkpoint reminders; completion tracking with audit trail; escalation for incomplete assessments

solutions.title: Parallel Investigation Teams
solutions.description: Establish minimum staffing requirements ensuring routine security monitoring continues during incident response
solutions.implementation: Create formal 'business as usual' teams that cannot be reassigned to incident response without executive approval. Implement rotating incident response assignments to prevent team exhaustion. Define clear boundaries: IR team handles active incident, BAU team maintains routine monitoring and investigates new alerts. Minimum 30% of security staff must remain on BAU during any incident.
solutions.technical_controls: Staffing assignment system with role enforcement; automated workload balancing; BAU coverage monitoring; alert routing based on team assignments

solutions.title: Stress Circuit Breakers
solutions.description: Implement mandatory pause protocols when incident response exceeds defined stress thresholds
solutions.implementation: Define stress triggers: multiple critical alerts, response time >4 hours, executive escalation, team fatigue indicators. Automatic activation of circuit breakers requiring 15-minute team huddles every 2 hours during extended incidents to reassess scope and approach. External perspective requirement for incidents lasting >8 hours (consultant, different team, or senior review). Documented pause and reassessment in incident timeline.
solutions.technical_controls: Stress indicator monitoring; automated circuit breaker triggers; timer-based huddle reminders; external reviewer notification system

solutions.title: Cross-Functional Review Panels
solutions.description: Establish mandatory consultation requirements with network, application, and compliance teams for all critical/high severity incidents
solutions.implementation: Create standardized consultation templates with specific questions each team must answer: Network team verifies lateral movement checks, App team confirms application-layer attack vectors assessed, Compliance validates regulatory implications considered. Implement escalation triggers when consultation reveals conflicting information or missed vectors. Include cross-functional review in incident closure criteria.
solutions.technical_controls: Consultation workflow automation; cross-team notification system; response collection and analysis; conflict detection and escalation

solutions.title: Automated Scope Assessment Tools
solutions.description: Deploy security orchestration tools that automatically correlate incidents across time windows, attack vectors, and affected systems
solutions.implementation: Configure SOAR platform to automatically analyze: (1) temporal correlation - similar incidents in past 72 hours, (2) systemic correlation - same attack patterns across different systems, (3) user correlation - targeting patterns, (4) TTP correlation - matching tactics/techniques/procedures. Generate automated scope assessment reports requiring analyst review before declaring incidents 'contained'. Alert for potential multi-vector attacks based on statistical patterns.
solutions.technical_controls: SOAR platform configuration; correlation rule development; automated scope report generation; analyst workflow requiring scope review; statistical anomaly detection

solutions.title: Post-Incident Red Team Reviews
solutions.description: Conduct structured red team reviews within 48 hours of incident resolution specifically looking for missed indicators and alternative attack vectors
solutions.implementation: Establish dedicated red team (internal or external) that reviews all critical incidents within 48 hours of resolution. Review focuses on: indicators present but not detected, attack vectors not investigated, scope limitations that may have missed activity. Include external security consultants in reviews for critical incidents. Maintain database of 'missed indicators' to identify tunnel vision patterns and training needs. Feed findings back into detection rules and training programs.
solutions.technical_controls: Red team review workflow; missed indicator database; pattern analysis tools; training program integration; detection rule update process

risk_scenarios.title: Multi-Vector Distraction Attacks
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers launch obvious, noisy attacks (DDoS, defacements, ransomware) to trigger tunnel vision, then execute their primary objective (data exfiltration, lateral movement, credential harvesting) while security teams focus exclusively on the distraction
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Coordinated multi-stage attack with obvious distraction preceding stealthy primary attack
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Stress-induced attentional narrowing causes teams to focus exclusively on loud, obvious threats while missing subtle sophisticated activity
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target 2013 breach - overwhelming alerts caused teams to miss sophisticated APT indicators while focused on known threat patterns

risk_scenarios.title: Crisis Amplification Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: During natural business crises (earnings releases, regulatory audits, system migrations), attackers exploit organizational stress by launching attacks knowing that tunnel vision will prevent comprehensive threat assessment
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Timing attacks to coincide with known organizational stress periods when tunnel vision is most severe
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Pre-existing organizational stress amplifies attentional narrowing, reducing peripheral threat detection capacity
risk_scenarios.historical_example: COVID-19 pandemic - widespread exploitation of organizational stress and tunnel vision on operational continuity rather than security

risk_scenarios.title: Authority-Based Social Engineering During Incidents
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers impersonate executives during high-stress incident response when employees are already under pressure, exploiting tunnel vision to bypass normal verification procedures
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: CEO fraud, executive impersonation, fake incident responder during active security incidents
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Incident-induced tunnel vision prevents verification behaviors; stress reduces prefrontal cortex control over automatic compliance
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple BEC incidents during security crises when verification procedures bypassed due to incident focus

risk_scenarios.title: Complex Attack Staging
risk_scenarios.description: Sophisticated attackers use initial compromise to create ongoing low-level stress through system instability or performance issues, then exploit the resulting tunnel vision to execute advanced persistent threat activities while security teams remain focused on system reliability rather than security indicators
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Multi-stage attack creating chronic stress conditions before executing primary objectives
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Chronic stress from system issues creates persistent tunnel vision preventing recognition of APT indicators
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Equifax 2017 - organizational stress from handling multiple simultaneous vulnerabilities created tunnel vision preventing proper coordination
